p: Figure 1 presents the density of bird positions per 1° × 1° cell for each winter month (wintering period). On figure 2, bird positions were summed by longitude and latitude for each non-breeding month (migration + wintering periods). Over the study period (2009–2015), GLS recordings showed that little auks migrated to their wintering grounds in October ( figure 2). Birds wintered off Newfoundland, between 40° N and 55° N and 35° W and 55° W, at nearly 3000 km from their colony. They remained within this area until February, and migrated towards their breeding grounds in March ( figure 2). Figure 2 shows a clear overlap between little auk distribution and peaks of C. finmarchicus abundance over the winter months. Hence, the timing of migration matched the narrowing (October) and broadening (March) of the C. finmarchicus distribution in the North Atlantic.
